727541f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, adjoining the S.E. corner of King
Road, Flushing, at the College Point spur of the Long Island
Railroad, showing an old house which later became the Church
of Christ in God (colored). The railroad spur was removed and
the house, too, was razed several years later, when the Boulevard
was widened.
View 1: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection 1922
View 2,3: P.L. Sperr
View 2: March 12, 1932
View 3: August 3, 1935
727541f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727543f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, between Kings Road (right) and Prince Street (left), showing in the center of view, No. 47, a
2 1/2-story structure once occupied by Peck and Fairweather's Crockery Store.
The Long Island, north branch, Railroad, now abandoned, extended
northward beyond the building at the right.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
727543f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727115f-a.text:
(1)
Junction Boulevard, at the N.E. corner of Northern Boulevard,
showing in process of demolition the home of Chas. P. Leverich from 1873-1891.
October 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, showing the house in the way of the widening of Northern Boulevard.
October 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
727115f-a.folder: Junction Boulevard & Nothern Boulevard, Queens, NY

727115f-b.folder: Junction Boulevard & Nothern Boulevard, Queens, NY

727538f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, east from near Kings
Road, Flushing, showing old buildings that were later
razed for the widening of the thoroughfare. The three-
story building, in front of which the truck is parked, is
the former Board of Education Building, at the S.W. corner
of Prince Street.
View 3 shows the Board of Education Building, looking
westward across Prince Street.

P. L. Sperr                        Views 1,2: Aug. 5, 1935
View 3: Aug. 24, 1935
727538f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727539f-c.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, west from King Road,
Flushing, showing some of the buildings that were later torn
down when the Boulevard was widened. The farther frame house,
at the S.W. corner of Lawrence Street, is the old Mrs. A. Peeks
house. Views 2 and 3 show the demolition, view 3 being from
Prince Street, a block west of King Road.

P. L. Sperr                      View 1: August 24, 1935
View 2: April 19, 1936
View 3: October 18, 1936
727539f-c.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727542f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, at the S.E. corner of King Road, Flushing, showing the Cities Service gas station, now abandoned. On the left is the Church of God in Christ. A few years later the buildings were torn down when the Boulevard was widened.

August 24, 1935
P.L. Sperr
727542f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727555f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, west from King Road, Flushing, across
Lawrence Street, showing the old Flushing River draw bridge.
At the S.W. corner of Lawrence Street is the Peeks house of
1873. When Northern Boulevard was widened some years later
all the buildings on the south side were razed and the trolley
tracks torn up.
August 24, 1935
Views 1, 2
P.L. Sperr
727555f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727540f-a.text:
Northern Boulevard, south side, between King Road and
Prince Street, showing the clearance created by the demolition
of buildings for the widening of the Boulevard. Shown, too,
are the rears of old homes on the west side of Prince Street,
and the Ebenezer Baptist Church (colored).
View 1: August 5, 1935
View 2: July 10, 1936
P.L. Sperr
727540f-a.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727540f-b.folder: Northern Boulevard & Kings Road, Queens, NY

727714f-b.text:
Queens Boulevard, at Jackson Avenue, showing the maze of elevated structures of the I.R.T. and B.M.T. subway systems on the former. The clock tower of the Bank of Manhattan Building can be seen in view 1. View 2 shows Krohn's diner on Jackson Avenue (S.W. corner) and the clock tower of the Brewster Building, and the nine-story building of the
Queens Light and Power Company.
P. L. Sperr  December 29, 1936
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 1,2
727714f-b.folder: Queens Boulevard & Jackson Avenue, Queens, NY
